Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery column-krater with handle roots; interior glazed; exterior: on shoulder, trace of frieze, perhaps part of possible leg; brown band below; between handle roots upper part of swan, to left; on right, part of possible palmette or wing, partially fired red; drill hole in broken edge from sampling for clay analysis.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The clay was analysed by M. Hughes and found to be Attic: Harbottle, G., Hughes, M. J. and Seleem, S. 'The Origin of black-figure Greek ceramics found in Naucratis (Nile Delta)', Archaeometry 47, 2005, 511-8; p.513, table 1, no.2
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 269, no. B205) (wrongly listed as G128.6)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0144) (Phase 1)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
